prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 Continuum: RX J1028.6-0844
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This project is designed to measure the far-infrared continuum luminosity at band 7 for RX J1028.6-0844.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We estimate the expected flux density at 350 GHz for our targets using their flux densities at 1.4 GHz with the assumption of spectral index as -1, which is a fairly conservative approach given the spectral energy distributions (SEDs) of the general RLQ population. Furthermore, we also expect higher far-infrared luminosity for our targets than typical RLQs. The expected 350 GHz flux density for this target is 1.1 mJy. Thus we require a continuum sensitivity of 0.1 mJy, which gives the SNR ~ 11. With the proposed 12-m array configuration, the needed time for this target is 24.44 minutes. None of our targets reside at Declination > +20 degree. There is no antenna shadowing problem in our proposed observations.
Our goal is to obtain B7 band continuum around 870 micron (observed frame). We do not need special correlator setup.
We do not need to resolve our targets for the purpose of the proposed study. Thus an angular resolution of 0.5 arcsec should be sufficient.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 Continuum: SDSS J1420+1205 and SDSS J1412+0624
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The project is designed to measure the far-infrared continuum luminosity at Band 7 for SDSS J1420+1205 and SDSS J1412+0624.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We estimate the expected flux density at 350 GHz for our targets using their flux densities at 1.4 GHz with the assumption of spectral index as -1, which is a fairly conservative approach given the spectral energy distributions (SEDs) of the general RLQ population. Furthermore, we also expect higher far-infrared luminosity for our targets than typical RLQs. The expected 350 GHz flux density for the two targets are 0.3 mJy and 0.2 mJy, respectively. Thus we require a continuum sensitivity of 0.03 mJy, which gives the SNR >6. With the proposed 12-m array configuration, the total needed time for the two targets is 2.74 hours. None of our targets reside at Declination > +20 degree. There is no antenna shadowing problem in our proposed observations.
Our goal is to obtain B7 band continuum around 870 micron (observed frame). We do not need special correlator setup.
We do not need to resolve our targets for the purpose of the proposed study. Thus an angular resolution of 0.5 arcsec should be sufficient.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA observations of 15 highly radio-loud quasars at z>4 to obtain their far-infrared luminosity and investigate its correlation with their X-ray luminosity. A positive correlation between these two quantities may indicate a dominating jet-linked X-ray emission mechanism of inverse Compton scattering of the host-galaxy photon field produced by a starburst. With this mechanism, the enhanced star-forming activity at high redshifts can also explain the X-ray emission enhancement of these objects over their counterparts at lower redshifts. The lack of such far-infrared/X-ray correlation would support an alternative mechanism of the inverse Compton scattering of the cosmic microwave background photons.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, Macalester College
